text: you brought up the issue of violence in
the african-american community the
figures are dismal aren't they professor
Orlando Patterson from Harvard
University gives some pretty stark
figures and I'm sure you'll agree with
african-americans 13% of the US
population but they commit 50% of
homicides 80% of homicides are black on
black black men are killing other black
men african-americans are imprisoned at
eight times the rate of whites and one
in three blacks as a prison record
what's going wrong in the African
American community when you look at the
level of education when you look at
poverty when you look at health when you
look at jobs and skills and the
opportunity for someone to self-sustain
poverty should never be an excuse for
people to commit crime or be engaged in
violence but it is absolutely one of the
contributing factors to a circumstance
that for some will leave them thinking
that they have no other alternative but
to engage with other people in that way
now again that's not an excuse but it's
a part of an explanation of what is
going on because not all poor and
unemployed people resort to violence of
course not
the overwhelming majority of poor or
unemployed people black or white Latino
or Asian are not engaged in crime the
vast majority of Americans are
law-abiding citizens there's no question
about it so what you usually have in
most cities in a country is a relatively
small group of people creating a
significant amount of havoc in their
little house and again policing is a
component of it but the police
department is not the all all in
solution at the violence in America we
should be investing more in education
and job training programs we should not
be cutting the Community Development
Block Grant program we should have a
transportation bill that lasts more than
six months or a year or two that's about
jobs when people are educated and can
get a job they're not involved in
violence they're not involved in crime
because they're too busy working of
course the kind of thing is you refer to
for instance in September this year the
national unemployment rate in the United
States was seven percent but for African
Americans it was nearly double that at
13 percent but talking about this small
group of people you say in the
african-american community who are
responsible for the violence take the
flash mobs which we've seen in
adelphia groups of young
african-americans going in packs
terrorizing neighborhoods popular
tourist neighborhoods and so on now you
have said when that has happened you
said to these youngsters you have
damaged your own race what do you mean
by that that was a couple years ago and
I would suggest that the flash mobs
however they might be described they're
certainly not limited to the
african-american community in all kinds
of folks kind of going while what I
meant by that is really comes from a
deep-seated training from my parents and
grandparents and folks kind of going
back many many years where you are
responsible for how you present yourself
out in the community and that you can
hurt the image of your own race by
engaging in certain race like that when
you're a mayor for all of Philadelphia
40 percent of your population but no
matter what title I might have I'm a
black guy from West Philadelphia a part
of the city of Philadelphia and I was
speaking to a particular audience and a
particular group of folks and I
understand I'm absolutely mayor of all
the people but I was trying to deliver a
particular message to a particular group
that was engaged in a particular set of
behaviors
I needed to address them tough message
you use you say things to
african-american males pull up your
trousers you know because they like to
wear their trousers alone without the
belt and you know nobody wants to see
your underwear you say you talk about
how generally not used to talk about how
their hair is unkempt and they should
comb their hair they should not just
limit themselves to the kind of black
slang that they use they should extend
their vocabulary you talk about the fact
that whites get out of elevators when
blacks go in or people cross the other
side of the street when they see young
black males and so on
are you not buying into racial
stereotypes yourself when you use that
kind of strong language no I'm speaking
of truth sometimes you just have to tell
the truth and I have a particular
perspective as a young black guy growing
up in a neighborhood in Philadelphia so
quite honestly I get to talk about some
things that other people either can't
talk about or won't talk about and I say
it in a way that communicates a message
to a particular group of folks that if
you want a future in the United States
of America
then there are certain things
you need to do you have to go to school
you need to graduate you should go onto
college a university or a trade school
and your face you said it might make it
a little more it might make it a little
more difficult for you to get a job so
you know it's already tough for black
men in the african-american community in
general the stats that you laid out over
time black unemployment has generally
been higher than the national average so
there are just some things that you have
to do or straight something about
